p.s: StarrsStarr's situation and how her state of mind effects her actions is shown by the use of a specific point of view and various narrative techniques.
The excerpt is written in a first person narrator.
The story is told by the main character - here Starr - and used pronouns are I, me, my.
The reader only knows what the protagonist knows as it is their subjective perspective.
This point of view has a rather personal effect on the reader, as the emotions and thoughts of Starr are described.
It can simply create a connection between reader and protagonist because the reader easy identifies with the character.
Still this point of view is very limited and subjective, throughout the fact that one only knows what Starr feels and what she says about other characters in the book.
If she portraitsportrays them in a certain state, the reader has little chances of creating a picture themselfthemselves.
According to that, one almost automaticlyautomatically sympathises with Starr, because one is nearer to her negative emotions and the bad things that happen to her.
The first narrative technique is in lines five to seven.
When they come to the protest, Starr remembers the night, because it is the same scenery.
[...] and see him lying in the street.The whole thing plays before my eyes [...].He looks at me for the last time and(ll. 6-7).
The narrative technique used here is a flashback with a panoramic mode.
The scene is not relived in the fullest, but told about.
This makes it seem more passive, because the reader does not know exactly what she remembers, even if one knows what happened with Khalil.
Starr's state of mind is shown here very distracted.
She loses focus of the actual scene happening and zooms out: I stare too hard, the crowd disappears (ll. 5-6).
The cut after the and underlines how absence she was and how her thoughts are interrupted by Ms. Ofrah's A hairbrush is not a gun!.
A second flashback is in lines 19 and 20 to 21.
As everybody starts shouting Starr gets a flashback to KhalilsKhalil's death.
First, only how he put his hairbrush into the side door (l. 19).
Then it is interrupted by a mutter of Starr how a hairbrush is not a gun (l. 20).
It goes on with He opens the door to ask if I'm okay.Then pow-pow- (ll. 21-22) as she sees how he is getting murdered once again.
This flashback also has a cut, but this time it is Starr shouting and raising her voice all emotional.
It is a turning point for Starr.
At first she only mutters, but as she rememberremembers and for the moment where she knows that she can notcannot be quiet anymore.
Furthermore, there are some interior monologues along the excerpt.
For example when she talks in her head about how it is weird seeing her attourneyattorney on a car.
Additionally, in line 44 when Starr stands on the car and is handed the bullhorn.
She does not know what to say and thinks Shit, I have no idea what to say and also in line 48: You know what?Fuck it.
This has the effect that the reader can experience along with her thoughts and sees the process.
Overall one can say that this excerpt shows Starr's development in the book.
It summarizes it in one specific scene, how she was totoo afraid to speak but then could and spoke out.
